questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with West syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Café au lait

Café au lait is a neurocutaneous marker seen in neurofibromatosis, not a component of West syndrome.
The triad of West syndrome is:
- Infantile spasms (also called Salaam spells)
- Developmental regression
- Hypsarrhythmia (abnormal EEG)
West syndrome is treated with:
- ACTH injections
- Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis

questions.text: A patient with HIV infection that has progressed to AIDS had been treated previously for cytomegalovirus pneumonia. For which additional CMV disease would this patient also be at risk?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Retinitis

CMV, which is usually asymptomatic or causes mild symptoms in immuno-competent persons, can cause a variety of devastating diseases in patients with AIDS, including retinitis.

questions.text: Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of treatment in patients with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura 

Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of the treatment of patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). The best response to this therapy is seen in patients with ADAMTS13 autoantibodies. Plasmapheresis is continued until the resolution of platelet count and signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days.

questions.text: Which among the following options is the most common cause of death in patients undergoing blood transfusions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Transfusion-related acute lung injury

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is the most common cause of transfusion-related fatalities. TRALI is due to the presence of anti-HLA class II antibodies in the donor plasma. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes, which aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. Multiparous women are frequently implicated donors. Recipients with a history of liver disease, smoking. Alcohol use are at a higher risk.

questions.text: Which of the following serological markers is positive in ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ANCA

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) positivity is a feature of ulcerative colitis. ASCA (anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody), anti- pancreatic antibody, and anti-flagellin antibody positivity are seen in Crohn’s disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. The following finding was noted on examination. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dermatomyositis

The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash. The given clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with the characteristic heliotrope rash and history of an internal malignancy point towards a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with history of gout is now diagnosed with hypertension. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Losartan

Losartan is the drug of choice for the management of hypertension in a patient with gout because of its uricosuric action. Thiazides (hydrochlorothiazide, metolazone) and loop diuretics (furosemide) cause reduced excretion of uric acid from the renal tubules and result in hyperuricemia. Therefore they are not preferred for management of hypertension in patients with gout.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with Crohn’s disease presents with back pain and stiffness. The physician suspects ankylosing spondylitis and orders an MRI for evaluation. Which of the following joints will be the earliest to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sacroiliac joint

The earliest joint to be involved in ankylosing spondylitis is the sacroiliac joint. Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is an inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the axial skeleton. It is more common in males, usually presenting between 20-30 years of age.

questions.text: Which is the most common cardiac valvular lesion seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mitral regurgitation

The most common cardiac valvular lesion seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presented with fever, malaise, skin rashes, and arthralgia. On further evaluation, his serology was positive for ANA and anti-histone antibodies. Use of which of the following drugs could have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hydralazine
The given clinical scenario with positive ANA and anti- histone antibodies point towards a diagnosis of drug- induced lupus erythematosus. Hydralazine which is a vasodilator is associated with the development of drug- induced lupus erythematosus.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with Felty syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hepatomegaly

Hepatomegaly is not seen in Felty syndrome.

Felty syndrome is defined by the clinical triad of:
•    Neutropenia
•    Splenomegaly
•    Rheumatoid arthritis
It occurs in the late stages of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

questions.text: What type of hypersensitivity reaction is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type III

Type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex deposition) is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus.

choices.text: Most commonly involves the first MTP joint

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient receiving anti-tubercular therapy has been recently diagnosed with gout. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The crystals are positively birefringent

In gout, the crystals are negatively birefringent on polarized light microscopy of the joint aspirate. Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the ER with colicky abdominal pain. His mother tells you that he refuses to walk due to knee pain. On examination, palpable purpura is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Henoch Schonlein purpura

The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of CREST syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Renal failure
Renal failure is not a component of CREST syndrome.
CREST syndrome is seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (IcSSc) and consists of the following:
•    Calcinosis cutis
•    Raynaud’s phenomenon
•    Esophageal dysmotility
•    Sclerodactyly

questions.text: An 11-year-old child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever and having no valvular pathology comes to your clinic. What is the duration of prophylaxis given to this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

10 years
The duration of prophylaxis given to this child is 10 years. The given scenario is a case of acute rheumatic fever without carditis and no valvular pathology. The secondary prophylaxis for this child is given for 5 years or till the age of 21, whichever is longer. Since the boy is 11 years old, prophylaxis for 10 years till the age of 21 years is longer than 5 years. 
ARF is an autoimmune disease that develops in response to group A streptococcal infection. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 5-14 years. An upper respiratory tract infection with some M serotypes of the organism is the trigger. The concept of molecular mimicry is used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition.

questions.text: A woman presents with altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, and bradycardia. Examination revealed non-pitting edema of the extremities. She has a long-standing history of weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The given clinical history suggests a typical case of hypothyroidism, and the likely diagnosis is myxedema coma. Myxedema coma is a severe neurological complication of hypothyroidism. It is primarily seen in the elderly and has a high mortality rate of 20-40%. It is often precipitated by the following factors:
• Drugs like sedatives, antidepressants, and anesthetics
• Infections like pneumonia
• Congestive heart failure, myocardial ischemia
• Cerebrovascular accidents
• Gastrointestinal bleeding
• Exposure to cold

choices.text: Start ATT after laparotomy and stricture removal

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. A radiograph of the chest is shown below. Ascitic fluid analysis showed elevated adenosine deaminase. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Start anti-tubercular therapy
This clinical vignette is suggestive of tuberculous peritonitis secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. Anti-tubercular therapy should be started as the next step in the management of this condition.
This patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss, and a radiograph showing a homogenous dense infiltrate in the right lung is consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). The presence of ascites along with the above-mentioned signs and symptoms is suggestive of tuberculous peritonitis.
The various pathogenic mechanisms of gastrointestinal TB include direct seeding into the abdomen due to swallowing of the sputum, hematogenous seeding of tubercle bacilli from rupture of lymph nodes or intraabdominal organs, and ingestion of milk from cows infected with bovine TB. It presents with abdominal pain, swelling, obstruction, hematochezia, and a palpable abdominal mass. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, night sweats, and anorexia are also present.
The terminal ileum and cecum are the most commonly involved sites.
The presence of fever, abdominal pain, and ascites should raise the suspicion of tuberculous peritonitis. The clinical presentation may be similar to Crohn's disease if the intestinal wall is involved, leading to ulcerations and fistulae.
Paracentesis reveals an exudate with high protein content, lymphocytosis, and elevated levels of adenosine deaminase(ADA). Elevated ADA levels have very high sensitivity for tuberculous peritonitis. Standard anti-tubercular therapy is recommended for ascites caused by tuberculous peritonitis. If the etiology of the ascites is uncertain, laparoscopy with peritoneal biopsy for culture and histology remains the gold standard.

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest x-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infrascapular region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The above X-ray and symptoms are suggestive of pleural effusion secondary to a lower respiratory tract infection. On examination, dullness to percussion will be observed.

questions.text: What is the most common genetic abnormality seen in patients with recurrent history of venous thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Factor V Leiden mutation
Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of venous thrombosis. Venous thrombosis typically manifests as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary thromboembolism.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating sensation, and weight loss. History is significant for stools that are bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. Further testing reveals fecal fat excretion of 8.2g/day. Which of the following would be a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Short bowel syndrome

The above scenario is suggestive of steatorrhoea, which is seen in short bowel syndrome. Steatorrhoea is defined as excess fat in stools (>7g/day) due to poor absorption of lipids. It is characterized by stools are bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a malabsorption disorder caused by a lack of functional small intestine. It can lead to the typical features of malabsorption such as abdominal pain, diarrhoea, steatorrhoea, weight loss and anaemia.

choices.text: Platelet aggregation tests with epinephrine and ADP are normal

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ristocetin aggregation test is normal

The ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal (no aggregation) in patients with Bernard-Soulier (BS) syndrome. It is an inherited disorder of platelet function or qualitative platelet disorder due to deficiency of the Gp Ib-IX receptor. This is the platelet membrane receptor for the von Willebrand factor (vWF). The binding of the vWF to the Gplb- IX-V complex on the platelet membrane is essential for platelet adhesion to the vessel wall.

questions.text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in patients with polycythemia vera?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

JAK2 mutation

The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation.

questions.text: What is the earliest radiographic feature of Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Aphthous ulcer

Aphthous ulcers seen in Crohn’s disease are the earliest radiological signs on small bowel follow-through study. They are shallow ulcers that are often multiple and separated by normal intervening mucosa. They are also the earliest macroscopic findings of Crohn’s disease.

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis & WHO staging?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Oral candidiasis & WHO stage 3 

Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO stage 3. Oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia are oral lesions categorized as WHO clinical stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are characteristically seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to mutations in the WASP gene.

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with long acting insulin

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) for which the next best step in management would be intravenous fluids with regular insulin.
DKA is a complication of diabetes mellitus that arises due to relative or absolute insulin deficiency, seen more commonly in patients with diabetes mellitus type 1. Clinical features include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and tachycardia. Hyperglycemia leads to volume depletion and subsequent hypotension. Kussmaul respiration and fruity odor on the breath are characteristic of the condition. Investigation shows elevated glucose levels (250-600 mg/dL), ketonemia, and metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the drug of choice for acute management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sumatriptan

The clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute attack of migraine and the drug of choice for acute management is sumatriptan.
Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches and is seen more commonly in women. It presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia). Common triggers include bright lights, sounds, and hunger. Triptans are 5-HT1B and 5-HT1D receptor agonists and they act by arresting the nociceptive nerve signaling in the trigeminovascular system. In addition, they cause cranial vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intravenous nitroglycerine

The clinical vignette along with the X-ray given points to a diagnosis of acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It can be managed by the administration of intravenous nitroglycerin.
Acute severe hypertension, acute myocardial infarction, or exacerbation of chronic heart failure are some of the common causes of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It can be precipitated by the discontinuation of medications (non-compliant patient), excessive salt intake, or tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sarcoidosis 

The given clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

questions.text: How many goals does the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) comprise of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

17

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) are comprised of 17 goals. These were set as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030. These goals consist of a total of 169 targets. SDGs replaced the Millennium Development Goals on 1st January 2016.

questions.text: Which of the following is not transmitted by lice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Q fever

Q fever is not transmitted by lice. It is spread by the inhalation of contaminated aerosols containing Coxiella burnetti.

questions.text: An intern sustains a needlestick injury while drawing blood from a Hepatitis B positive patient. Assuming he has been infected, which among the following will be the first to rise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HBsAg
HbsAg is the first serological marker to be detected in Hepatitis B infection.

Implementation in over 10 districts in 5 states
Subcentre has facility for diagnosis and treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

District hospital has specialized facilities

District hospital has specialized facilities for the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS).

questions.text: Identify the organization that has the given emblem:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

National Leprosy Eradication Programme

The given image is the emblem of National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP).

questions.text: Which of the following methods of purification of water cannot be used on a large scale?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Berkefeld filter
Berkefeld filter is used for the purification of water on a small scale (ex: in households).

choices.text: Information, education, communication and public awareness

questions.text: An ASHA worker is offering services under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in her village. All of the following services will be provided by her except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Water pollution control
Water pollution is not managed under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was launched in 2014 with an aim to eradicate open-air defecation by the year 2019 through the construction of 12 million toilets. The two sub- missions of Swachh Bharat Abhiyan are Swachh Bharat Mission Gramin (SBM-G) and Swachh Bharat Mission Urban (SBM-U).

questions.text: Droplet precaution and isolation is to be done for all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Localized varicella zoster

Droplet precaution and isolation is not done for localized varicella zoster, as it is only transmitted through direct contact.

questions.text: A banker who is scheduled to travel to Congo is advised to take the yellow fever vaccine. What is the flight range of the mosquito which transmits this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

100 metres

Yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. Its flight range is 100 metres.

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Infant mortality rate
The infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index. The Global Hunger Index (GHI) has three dimensions. These dimensions are measured by indicators.

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Disaster impact- Response -  Rehabilitation – Mitigation

questions.text: Project “Axshya” is in relation to controlling which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tuberculosis


Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means ‘free from TB’ which is the ultimate goal of the project and the national TB programme. Project Axshya is being implemented by The International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

questions.text: Given below is an instrument which is used to measure air humidity. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anemometer

An anemometer is an instrument that measures wind speed and wind pressure. Anemometers are important tools for meteorologists, who study weather patterns.

questions.text: Which vaccine is crucial for pregnant women to protect their newborns from pertussis (whooping cough)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tdap vaccine

The Tdap vaccine is recommended for pregnant women during each pregnancy to protect their newborns from pertussis (whooping cough).

questions.text: Which vaccine is typically given to newborns within 24 hours of birth to prevent a specific type of hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hepatitis B vaccine

The Hepatitis B vaccine is typically given to newborns within 24 hours of birth to protect against hepatitis B, a serious liver infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in Acute Intermittent Porphyria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thiopentone

Thiopentone is a barbiturate that induces enzyme activity, which can precipitate an acute episode of porphyria. Therefore, it is absolutely contraindicated in patients with a history of acute intermittent porphyria.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

LMA ProSeal 

The top image depicts the LMA ProSeal, recognizable by its dual tubes — one for the airway and another for gastric drainage, which prevents gastric insufflation and pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: Which anesthetic agent is most commonly associated with postoperative delirium and hallucinations due to its unique pharmacological properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ketamine

Explanation: Ketamine, often used as an anesthetic to induce loss of consciousness, can lead to postoperative delirium and hallucinations. This is primarily due to its action as an NMDA receptor antagonist, which contributes to its dissociative anesthesia properties. It affects the thalamo-cortical junction, leading to an altered perception of the environment and vivid imagery.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient with COVID-19 requires supplemental oxygen. Which color of the oxygen cylinder should be used to deliver oxygen to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Black body with white shoulder

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoes general anesthesia for an emergency appendectomy in a hospital in Mumbai. Shortly after the administration of halothane and succinylcholine, she develops a rapid rise in end-tidal CO2, muscle rigidity, and a high fever. Suspecting a serious complication, the anesthesiologist should immediately consider which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Malignant hyperthermia
Malignant hyperthermia is a life-threatening genetic disorder triggered by certain anesthetic agents, including halothane and succinylcholine. It is characterized by a hypermetabolic state with symptoms such as rapid rise in end-tidal CO2, muscle rigidity, and elevated body temperature. Immediate recognition and treatment with dantrolene are crucial for patient survival.

choices.text: Failure to lose weight despite psychotherapy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Failure to lose weight despite psychotherapy
Failure to lose weight by an obese patient despite psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, and lifestyle modifications is an indication for metabolic surgery.

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative day following a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ERCP

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation in a patient suspected of post- cholecystectomy biliary leaks. Patients with post-cholecystectomy biliary leak usually present with fever, jaundice and abdominal pain. USG is used for an initial evaluation in such cases and can show a collection in the sub-hepatic space.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with a history of thromboembolic stroke is currently taking aspirin and warfarin. He is complaining of a headache and appears confused after a fall in the toilet last night. NCCT of the head was done. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma and neurosurgery consultation
The above clinical scenario and the plain computed tomography (CT) scan show a concave-convex- shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH). Since, the patient is on anticoagulants, reversal with Vitamin K, FFP and immediate neurosurgical consultation would be the next best step.

choices.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
Tumor more than the size of the breast

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for breast conservative surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis is not a contraindication for breast conservative surgery. Breast conservative therapy (BCT) involves resection of primary breast cancer with adequate normal breast tissue, adjuvant radiotherapy, and assessment of regional lymph nodes via a separate incision in the axilla.
Removal of primary breast cancer is also called lumpectomy/ tylectomy/ partial mastectomy/ wide local excision.
Absolute contraindications of BCT:
• Pregnancy
• Persistently positive margin (2 microscopy shows positive margins)
• Multicentric lumps
• Diffuse microcalcification
• Extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
• Inflammatory breast cancer
Relative contraindications of BCT:
• Active SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus), scleroderma
• Large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump)
• Known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), Li-Fraumeni syndrome (p53 mutation)
• Multifocal disease
• Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

questions.text: A patient scheduled for a thyroid radionuclide scan had consumed an  Iodine 123 containing pill at around 6 AM. What is the half-life of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

12-14 hours

The half-life of I123 is 12-14 hours.

Isotopes of lodine such as lodine-123 (123I) and lodine-131 (131I) are used to image the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident is put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

The patients GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.
It is calculated as follows:
Eye opening: Opening to verbal command – 3
Verbal response: In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT (non-testable)
Motor respone: Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously – 6

questions.text:
The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
1. Glasgow coma scale
2. Respiratory Rate
3. Pulse Rate
4. Systolic BP
5. Mechanism of Injury
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1,2 and 4
The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient.
Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes:
- Glasgow coma scale
- Respiratory rate
- Systolic BP
The score range is 0-12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury.

questions.text: eFAST is least helpful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Retroperitoneal hematoma
Among the given options, FAST (focussed assessment with sonography in trauma) is least useful in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma as the sensitivity of ultrasound for the detection of retroperitoneal hematomas is extremely poor.
