questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe testicular pain and swelling. On examination, the affected testicle is high-riding, tender, and has a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent. Which of the following statements about the condition is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

If torsion is confirmed, the recommended treatment involves administering antibiotics and analgesics and scheduling corrective surgery after 14 days.
Testicular torsion refers to the twisting of the spermatic cord, which supplies blood to the testicle. It is a urological emergency that requires immediate intervention to prevent testicular ischemia and potential loss of the testicle. The classic presentation of testicular torsion includes sudden-onset severe testicular pain, swelling, and tenderness. In the given clinical case, the high-riding testicle, tenderness, and absence of the cremasteric reflex (which is normally elicited by stroking the inner thigh and causes elevation of the testicle) strongly suggest testicular torsion. The horizontal lie of the testicle may be observed due to the twisting of the spermatic cord.  If torsion is confirmed, the recommended treatment involves administering antibiotics and analgesics and performing immediate corrective surgery.

questions.text: A newborn baby is examined shortly after birth and is found to have a visible bladder on the anterior abdominal wall. The bladder is exposed and not covered by the abdominal wall. The baby is otherwise healthy, and there are no other apparent abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bladder exstrophy

The most likely diagnosis in this case is Bladder exstrophy. Bladder exstrophy is a congenital malformation characterized by a visible bladder on the anterior abdominal wall due to the failure of the lower abdominal wall and the anterior wall of the bladder to fuse properly during embryonic development. The presentation of a visible bladder exposed and not covered by the abdominal wall shortly after birth is highly suggestive of bladder exstrophy. This condition is typically apparent at birth and may be associated with other abnormalities such as epispadias (malformation of the urethra).

choices.text: A conscious patient with a deep leg laceration, bleeding profusely.
An unconscious patient with no visible external injuries.
A conscious patient with a fractured arm and complaining of severe pain.
An unconscious patient with an open head injury and bleeding from the nose.

questions.text: During a major earthquake, a triage officer is responsible for assessing and prioritizing patients based on their medical needs. Several injured individuals are brought to the triage area simultaneously. Which patient should be prioritized for immediate medical attention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A conscious patient with a deep leg laceration, bleeding profusely
In disaster management triage, patients are assessed and prioritized based on the severity of their injuries or medical conditions. The triage officer follows a systematic approach to allocate limited resources effectively and save the maximum number of lives. The triage categories commonly used are:
1. Immediate (Red): Patients with life-threatening injuries who require immediate intervention to survive.
2. Delayed (Yellow): Patients with potentially serious injuries who can tolerate some delay in treatment.
3. Minimal (Green): Patients with minor injuries or illnesses who can wait for treatment.
4. Expectant (Black): Patients with severe injuries or medical conditions unlikely to survive despite treatment.
This patient exhibits uncontrolled bleeding, which can be life-threatening if not addressed promptly. Therefore, this patient falls under the Immediate (Red) category and should be prioritized for immediate medical attention.

questions.text: A patient presents following a motorcycle road traffic accident. There was no pain or injury. Examination shows blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. What will be your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suprapubic cystostomy

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a suspected urethral injury since there is blood at the urethral meatus. The next best step in the management is a suprapubic cystostomy.

questions.text: A patient was found to have a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach which involves the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis which should be managed with palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy.
Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch. The image given below shows Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain. Pancreatitis was suspected and a CT scan revealed echoic lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serum lipase
In an alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis, serum lipase is the enzyme most likely to be elevated.
Acute pancreatitis is diagnosed on the basis of clinical findings and elevated levels of pancreatic enzymes in the plasma. If the elevation of amylase and lipase levels is threefold or higher, then the diagnosis of pancreatitis is confirmed.

questions.text: A young man gets into a fight after taking beer and is kicked by the lower abdomen. There was pelvic fracture. Blood at meatus. Most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rupture of membranous urethra

questions.text: When a ‘spontaneous perforation’ of the esophagus occurs as a result of severe barotrauma while a person vomits against a closed glottis, the condition is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Boerhaave’s syndrome
Boerhaave syndrome is also known as spontaneous esophageal rupture or effort rupture of the esophagus. Although vomiting is thought to be the most common cause, other causes include those that can increase intra-esophageal pressure and cause a barogenic esophageal rupture.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presented with progressive jaundice, pruritus and clay colored stools for 2 months. History of waxing and waning of jaundice was present. A CT scan revealed dilated main pancreatic duct and common bile duct. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Periampullary carcinoma 

“The waxing and waning nature of jaundice is due to sloughing of ampullary cancer, resulting in transient resolution of the jaundice.”

choices.text: Junction between 2nd and 3rd part of duodenum

questions.text: In a burn patient, the doctor is looking for curling ulcer. Which part should be examined?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1st part of duodenum 
•    Cushing ulcer: Stress gastritis due to intracranial injury/increased ICP
•     Curling ulcer: After burn injury (> 35%); in the body and fundus; not in antrum and duodenum 
•    Cameron ulcers or riding ulcers: Linear gastric erosions in hiatal hernias

questions.text: Most common complication of ileostomy is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Skin irritation 

•    MC complication of ileostomy: Skin irritation

•     MC early complication of ileostomy: Ischemic necrosis

choices.text: Do an urgent upper GI endoscopy
Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
Insert a cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented to you with ongoing massive hematemesis. The patient is alert and hemodynamically stable. What will be the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway  
As a part of the BLS algorithm, we should start with the airway management in any patient who is collapsed/expected to collapse. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, the airway is the most important component at risk in this patient and requires immediate attention. The patient should be put in a recovery position i.e. left lateral decubitus position to prevent the risk of  aspiration.

choices.text: Within minutes to hours of transplantation

questions.text: Acute cellular rejection following solid organ transplantation occurs:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Between 5 to 30 days of transplantation

choices.text: Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Lateral and caudal to the upper pole ureter
Medial and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Medial and caudal to the upper pole ureter

questions.text: According to Weigert-Meyer’s rule of duplication of ureter, the lower pole ureter in urinary bladder is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Meyer-Weigert-Rule predicts the draining pattern of duplex ureters in bipolar renal duplications. The upper pole is normally seen as ectopic and therefore dysplastic due to obstruction, whereas the lower pole is related to vesicoureteral reflux.

questions.text: Hesselbach’s triangle is bounded by the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Transversus abdominis muscle

Indirect inguinal hernia comes out of abdominal cavity through deep inguinal ring, travel inguinal canal and becomes superficial through superficial inguinal ring. Direct inguinal hernia enters inguinal canal through medial half of weak posterior wall (Hesselbach’s triangle) and becomes superficial through superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insulinoma
The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is an insulinoma. The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Induration
ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration. Instead, the I in ASEPSIS stands for isolation of bacteria from the wound.
ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

questions.text: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lymphedema
Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long standing non-pitting edema in the limbs. Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the tissues. Usually, there is a balance between fluid formation and lymph transport capacity. With congenital hypoplasia or acquired obstruction, there is a reduction in transport capacity resulting in the accumulation of fluid and protein in the interstitium.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Partial nephrectomy

Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is performed for tumors less than 4 cm in size. It is also performed for:
• Bilateral RCC
• Carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney
• RCC in one kidney and hydronephrosis or calculi in the contralateral kidney
Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors.

questions.text: Germline mutations of which of the following genes is not associated with hereditary pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NF2 gene

Germline mutation in NF2 gene is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2, and not hereditary pheochromocytoma. Hereditary pheochromocytomas are associated with NF1 germline mutations.

choices.text: Wide excision involving the affected ducts

questions.text: What is the best method of management in a patient with recurrent episodes of multiple duct ectasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hadfield’s operation

The best method of management in a patient with multiple duct ectasia is to perform Hadfield’s operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bone curette
 The above image depicts a bone curette. Bone Curette is used for debridement or curettage during orthopedic surgical procedures. The instrument offers flexibility during the removal of fibrous tissues and debris from bones.

questions.text: A 4 month old child having complaints of high grade fever, decreased appetite and pain right hip. On examination he has dehydration, tenderness in scarpas triangle, swelling in right hip region/absent movements in right hip region. On X-ray there is mild increase in medial joint space. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Septic arthritis 

Patient is in first 5 years of life with absent movement at joint with toxic presentation goes towards septic arthritis.

questions.text: The shown brace is used in which condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Developmental displacement hypoplasia
The Pavlik harness is a soft splint. It is most commonly used for treating infants with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).

choices.text: Snail flattened femoral head lying outside the acetabulum
Thickened adherent joint capsule with an hour-glass constriction.

questions.text: In congenital dislocation of the hip (CDH), the pathological changes include the following except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Elongated femoral neck 
Following changes are seen in a dislocated joint in CDH:
Femoral head is dislocated upwards and laterally; its epiphysis is small and ossifies late.
•     Femoral neck is excessively anteverted.
•    Acetabulum is shallow, with a steep sloping roof. 
•    Ligamentum teres is hypertrophied.
•    Fibro- cartilaginous labrum of the acetabulum (limbus) may be folded into the cavity of the acetabulum (inverted limbus).
•     Capsule of the hip joint is stretched.
•    Muscles around the hip, especially the adductors, undergo adaptive shortening.

choices.text: Rheumatoid arthritis of the wrist joint

questions.text: A 25 years- old male complained of limitation of wrist movements, especially dorsiflexion, and weakness of the hand, especially the grip. Examination revealed radial deviation of the hand with abnormal prominence of the ulna. He gave a history of a fall on the outstretched hand in children. The correct diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Madelung's deformity

Madelung deformity refers to bowing of the radial shaft with increased interosseous space and dorsal subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint. This deformity is due to premature closure or defective development of the ulnar third of the distal physis of the radius.

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pancoast tumor

MRI is useful in Pancoast tumor because of the associated soft tissue infiltration, extent of which can be best visualised using an MRI. Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Craniopharyngioma
A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke’s pouch and arises near the pituitary stalk, commonly extending into the suprasellar cistern.

questions.text: Technetium-99m labelled heat-denatured RBC’s are used to diagnose pathology in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spleen

Technetium-99m labelled heat-denatured RBCs are used for specific splenic assessment and is gold-standard in splenosis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old-man presents with acute flank pain and hematuria. What is the most appropriate next imaging test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Unenhanced CT scan

Explanation:
For a patient presenting with acute flank pain and hematuria, the most likely clinical suspicion is renal colic due to urolithiasis (kidney stones). The unenhanced CT scan (CT KUB) is the gold standard imaging test in this scenario.
Rationale for Using Unenhanced CT:
1. High Sensitivity and Specificity:
o Unenhanced CT is highly accurate for detecting renal and ureteric stones.
o It allows visualization of the size, location, and density of the stones.
2. No Contrast Required:
o Contrast media can obscure the stones and is unnecessary for the initial diagnosis of urolithiasis.
o Additionally, patients with potential impaired renal function or contraindications to contrast are safeguarded.
3. Quick and Readily Available:
o CT KUB provides rapid results, which is critical in the acute setting.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you not see eggshell calcification of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bronchogenic carcinoma
Eggshell calcification of lymph nodes is not a feature of bronchogenic carcinoma. Eggshell calcification refers to fine calcification seen at the periphery of a lymph node. It may be seen in primary calcifying malignancies such as osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, colorectal, and ovarian tumors.

questions.text: Eye of tiger sign on MRI is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hallervorden Spatz syndrome 
The eye of tiger sign can be seen in Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome. The eye of the tiger sign refers to abnormal low T2 signal on MRI (due to abnormal accumulation of iron) in the globus pallidus with a longitudinal stripe of high signal (due to gliosis and spongiosis).

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Craniopharyngioma
A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke’s pouch and arises near the pituitary stalk, commonly extending into the suprasellar cistern.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is rushed to the ED with severe chest pain and is diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction. Which of the following can be used to assess the area of infarction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tc-99m pyrophosphate
Technetium 99m pyrophosphate is used in hot spot imaging in acute MI. It accumulates in the damaged myocardium and the area of infarct appears as a hot spot.

questions.text: What is the recommended dose limit of cumulative radiation exposure during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1 mSv
The recommended dose limit of cumulative radiation exposure during pregnancy is 1mSv.

questions.text: The following scan is of a young woman on oral contraceptives. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hepatic adenoma

The image given is of hepatic adenoma. It is the most frequent hepatic tumour in young women on oral contraceptive pills. Hepatic adenomas, also referred to as hepatocellular adenomas, are benign liver tumours and are generally hormone-induced.

questions.text: A female patient came to the hospital with a history of relapsing, remitting, mildly itchy erythematous plaques over the scalp, sacral area, and knees. She has a history of joint pain and her nail changes are shown ,in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Psoriasis
The diagnosis in this patient with the above clinical features is psoriasis. The image shows nail pitting, oil drop sign, and salmon patches in fingernails.
Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. The skin lesions can have exacerbations and relapse. They include red, silvery-white well-demarcated scales. A peripheral clearing known as the ring of Woronoff may be present. It is usually seen on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs. The appearance of a smooth, glossy red membrane with small bleeding points on the removal of the supra-papillary epidermis by gentle scraping is known as Auspitz's sign.

questions.text: Skin manifestations caused by the drug administered for amebic dysentery are due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fixed drug eruption
The skin manifestations are most commonly due to metronidazole, which is associated with fixed drug eruption (FDE). Although maculopapular rashes can also be seen with metronidazole, the incidence of a fixed drug eruption is higher with metronidazole.

questions.text: A 30-year-old presented with flaccid bullae on her skin which are easy to rupture. The biopsy revealed a suprabasal split. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pemphigus vulgaris

The given clinical vignette of a bullous disorder with the histologic picture pointing towards a suprabasal blister suggests the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris. It is caused due to the production of antibodies mainly against desmoglein 3. Rarely antibodies against desmoglein 1 can also be found. The antibodies are commonly IgG antibodies. Desmoglein 3 is mainly present in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following itchy cutaneous lesions to the OPD. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Lichen planus

The skin lesion in the above image shows characteristic purple, flat, polygonal papules seen in lichen planus. The lesions of lichen planus can be described as 5Ps purple, polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), papules.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of widespread pruritus for the past two weeks. The itching is particularly bad at night. He has no history of note and works in the local car factory. On examination he has noted to have a number of linear erythematous lesions in between his fingers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Scabies 
It is Superficial skin infection caused by arthropod Sarcoptes scabiei (mite). Severe itching at night. Too small to be seen by naked eye. Pathognomonic sign: burrows, linear markings in skin due to mites’ movements

questions.text: All of the following changes are seen in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased peripheral vascular resistance 
Ans. is d, i.e. Increased peripheral vascular resistance 
Blood volume increases during pregnancy Cardiac output = Stroke volume x Heart rate 
All these three parameters increase during pregnancy 
In pregnancy since the main hormone is progesterone, which has a smooth muscle relaxant effect so peripheral vascula resistance decreases during pregnancy (and not increases).

questions.text: A drop in fetal heart rate that typically last less than 2 minutes and usually associated with umbilical cord compression is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Variable deceleration

questions.text: A G3P2, pregnant comes to your clinic at 18 weeks of gestation for genetic counseling. She has a history of two kids born with thalassemia major. Which test would you recommend now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amniocentesis 
This patient has history of 2 kids with thalassemia major, hence definitive diagnosis is needed in this pregnancy. At 18 weeks, definitive diagnostic test is amniocentesis. Cordocentesis is difficult to perform before 20 weeks: “Before 20 weeks it is difficult to visualize the cord insertion and cord lumen is narrow.”

questions.text: A pregnant woman is found to have excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid.Such polyhydramnios is likely to be associated with all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bilateral renal agenesis

Fetal urine is the main contributor of Amniotic fluid beyond 20 weeks therefore. In case of Renal agenesis → decrease/no urine → oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A female at 37 weeks of gestation has mild labour pains for 10 hours and cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non effaced. What will be the next appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sedation and wait 
The patient is presenting at 37 weeks with mild labor pains for 10 hours. Cervix is 1 cms dilated and is not effaced Now this can either be a case of false labor pains or it can be prolonged latent phase of labor. False labor can be differentiated from latent phase of labor by therapeutic rest, i.e. patient is sedated with morphine.

questions.text: All of the following are included in first stage of labor except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Crowning of fetal head 

Crowning is a cardinal movement of labor, which occurs during second stage.

choices.text: Delivery of placenta by controlled cord tracton

questions.text: All of the following steps are recommended by WHO for preventing PPH except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

i.e. Uterine massage 
Prevention of PPH in other words means active management of third stage of labor (AMTSL). Earlier uterine massage was included in AMTSL, but now WHO does not recommend uterine massage as a compone of AMTSL. Uterine massage is now recommended by WHO in the treatment of PPH.

questions.text: Early cord clamping is indicated in all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

HIV positive females 
Indications of early cord clamping:
•    Maternal or fetal instability — if either needs resuscitation
•    IUGR baby with abnormal Doppler evaluation Known heart disease in baby 
•    If cord is avulsed

questions.text: Anticipated preterm delivery. Dose of dexamethasone given to mother is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

6 mg 12 hourty 4 doses 
Dose of Dexamethasone is 4 injections of 6 mg each, given @ 12 hourly interval intramuscularly. 
Dose of Betamethasone is 2 injections of 12 mg each, given @ 24 hours interval intramuscularly.

questions.text: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is detected to have lung metastasis. She should be Staged as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stage -III

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital abnormality in a baby of a diabetic woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ventricular septal defect 

Most common congenital abnormality in a baby of diabetic women is ventricular septal defect.

questions.text: A 27 year primigravida presents with pregnancy induced hypertension with blood pressure of 150/100 mm of Hg at 32 weeks of gestation with no other complications. Subsequently, her blood pressure is controlled on treatment. If there are no complications, the pregnancy should be terminated at:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

37 completed weeks
The patient in the question has BP 150/100 mm of Hg, i.e. mild hypertension (severe hypertension is when systolic BP is being managed expectantly) and has no other complications. Her BP is controlled on treatment, i.e. she in such patients pregnancy should be terminated at 37 weeks. 
“If Pregnancy is beyond 37 completed weeks termination is to be considered without delay.”

choices.text: Admit the patient, start antihypertensives and continue pregnancy till term
Admit the patient, start antihypertensives, MgSO, and terminate the pregnancy
Admit oral antihypertensives and follow-up in outpatient department

questions.text: A female of 36 weeks gestation presents with hypertension, blurring of vision and headache. Her blood pressure reading was 180/120 mm Hg and 174/110 mm Hg after 20 minutes. How will you manage the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Admit the patient, start antihypertensives, MgSO⁴, and terminate the pregnancy
 In the question, patient is presenting with: Headache, Blurring of vision, B/P = 180/120 mm of Hg (later 174/110 mm of Hg), i.e. she is a case of severe pregnancy induced hypertension. 
In severe pre-eclampsia there are 2 risks: 
1. Intracranial bleeding: Give antihypertensive 
2. Convulsions: Give MgSO⁴
Definitive management is Termination of pregnancy at > 34 weeks. Since this patient is 36 weeks pregnant, so option C is the best one. First step in the management of this case would be to prevent seizures, i.e. give MgSO⁴.

questions.text: A pregnant lady is suffering from SLE. Which of the following autoantibodies would be responsible if her child has congenital heart block?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anti-Rho 
Fetal and neonatal heart block results from diffuse myocarditis and fibrosis in the region between the atrioventricular node and bundle of His. Congenital heart block develops almost exclusively in fetuses of women with antibodies to the SS-A or SS-B antigens.

questions.text: In cephalic presentation with well-flexed head [fully flexed head] the presenting diameter is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suboccipito-bregmatic 
Suboccipito-bregmatic: from the center of anterior fontanelle (bregma) to the occipital protuberance, measuring 9.5 cm. This is the presenting diameter in vertex presentation. Suboccipito-frontal: from the anterior part of bregma to the occipital protuberance, measuring 10 cm.

questions.text: Which of following is false regarding stein leventhal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decreased fasting insulin

questions.text: Which of the following is not the function of OC pills as a contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Delayed Menstruation
 The progesterone is primarily responsible for preventing pregnancy.  The main mechanism of action is the prevention of ovulation; they inhibit follicular development and prevent ovulation. Progesterone negative feedback works at the hypothalamus to decrease the pulse frequency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone. This, in turn, will decrease the secretion of folliclestimulating hormone (FSH) and decreases the secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH).

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady presents with constant leakage of urine and dysuria two weeks after a complicated total abdominal hysterectomy. A diagnosis of Vesicovaginal fistula is suspected. The most important test for the diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Triple swab test 
Triple swab test is the investigation of choice to establish the diagnosis of a suspected vesicovaginal fistula. It confirms the presence of vesicovaginal fistula, and also differentiate it from uretero vaginal and urethro vaginal fistula.

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. Crown Rump Length was 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks on TVS. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Repeat TVS after one week
The given clinical scenario of a patient with amenorrhea presenting with spotting, raises a suspicion of possible abortion and in the given case the next line of management would be to repeat TVS after one week. In a normal intrauterine pregnancy a gestational sac will be visible on TVS by 5 weeks of LMP and the embryonic poles can be visualized by 5.5 weeks. The cardiac activity of the embryo can be first visualized on TVS around 5.5-6 weeks, when the crown rump length (CRL) is around 5mm.

questions.text: A 38-year old lady in her 6th week of gestation is concerned about Down’s syndrome and enquires about noninvasive prenatal testing. When is the earliest that the test can be undertaken?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

9 weeks

Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) can be done any time after 9-10 weeks, after which it is not dependent on the gestational age. NIPT is used for the screening of Trisomy 13, 18, 21, and Turner’s syndrome. It is not a diagnostic test. It is a novel genetic test that uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum for screening of chromosomal anomalies.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, her height is normal and the breast development is appropriate for her age. However, the axillary and pubic hair is sparse. On ultrasound, an absent uterus is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Androgen insensitivity syndrome
The patient has primary amenorrhea, and the most likely diagnosis is androgen insensitivity syndrome. Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder, in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor. They appear as phenotypically normal females at birth and often present with primary amenorrhea at puberty. External genitalia will appear normal with scant or absent pubic and axillary hair, shortened vagina. The uterus and fallopian tubes are absent. However, they develop breasts during pubertal maturation due to abundant androgen-to-estrogen conversion. Testes may be palpable in the labia or inguinal area or in the abdomen.

questions.text: According to Caldwell and Moloy’s classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Android pelvis
According to Caldwell and Moloy’s classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with the android pelvis.

questions.text: Which of the following signs suggests magnesium sulfate toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sluggish knee jerks
Loss of deep tendon reflexes like knee jerk reflex is a sign of magnesium toxicity.
Repeat injections of MgSO, are given only if knee jerks are present, urine output exceeds 30 ml/hr, and the and respiratory rate is more than 12/min.

questions.text: A young woman came to the clinic requesting a post-coital pill. Which of the following would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Levonorgestrel
Levonorgestrel can be prescribed to a young woman requesting a post-coital pill. Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, it can also be administered in two doses of 0.75 mg. The first dose is taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, and the 2nd dose is taken 12 hours apart. The tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval.

questions.text: A 75-year-old elderly female presents with a history of feeling a bulge in her vagina for the past several years. She reports worsening symptoms of pelvic pressure and discomfort. On examination, a protrusion is noted out of the vagina which is shown following. Most appropriate management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hysterectomy

The symptoms and examination findings are consistent with a vaginal prolapse. The most appropriate management in this scenario is hysterectomy, which is a surgical procedure to remove the uterus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding at 10 weeks gestation. On ultrasound, a “snowstorm” appearance with multiple cystic spaces and absence of fetal parts is noted within the uterine cavity. Her serum B-hCG levels are markedly elevated. Most appropriate next step in management:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


The symptoms and ultrasound findings are consistent with a molar pregnancy. The most appropriate next step in management is dilatation and curettage (D&C) to remove the abnormal tissue and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myomectomy
The most appropriate management for a woman with infertility due to intramural fibroids at both the cornual ends of the uterus is myomectomy. The cause for infertility, in this case, is due to the fibroids blocking the right and left cornua of the uterus. Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in women presenting with infertility, those who desire pregnancy, or those who wish to retain the uterus.
Intracavitary fibroids can be resected via the hysteroscopic approach, while subserosal or intramural fibroids require laparotomy or laparoscopic myomectomy.

questions.text: A 28-year old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

G2P1
The obstetric score of a pregnant woman who previously delivered twins would be G2P1 (gravida 2 para 1). The term gravida refers to the number of times the woman has been pregnant, irrespective of whether crossed the period of viability. The current pregnancy is included in this count. Since she has been pregnant once before with twins and is currently pregnant now, gravida will be 2.

questions.text: Antepartum hemorrhage due to abruption shows all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Painless vaginal bleeding
Painless vaginal bleeding is not a feature of abruption of the placenta. Patients with placental abruption present with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions. Painless vaginal bleeding can occur in placenta previa where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very close to the cervical os.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation?
1. Goodell's sign
2. Osiander's sign
3. Internal ballottement
4. Lightening
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1,2
The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign and Osiander's sign.
Goodell's sign is a sign of early pregnancy, which describes the marked softening of the cervix in contrast to the non-pregnant state. It is seen as early as the 6th week.
Osiander's sign describes the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity. It is seen around 8 weeks of gestation.
Internal ballottement can be elicited between 16-28th weeks of gestation, before which the fetus is too small and after which it is too large to displace. It may not be elicited in cases with scanty liquor amnii, or when the fetus is transversely placed.
Lightening is a sense of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part. It is felt at about 38 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice that began within the first 24 hours of life. On examination, the jaundice is conjugated, and the infant has acholic (pale) stools. Laboratory tests reveal elevated direct bilirubin and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Biliary atresia  

The presentation of persistent jaundice beginning within the first 24 hours of life, with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, acholic stools, and elevated GGT, raises concern for biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a congenital condition where there is a blockage or absence of the bile ducts, leading to impaired bile flow.

questions.text: A young infant is brought to you with a suspected developmental delay. The child is intently looking at his own hands. You would consider referring this child to a specialist if this milestone persists after.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

20 weeks

Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently. This milestone is called hand regard and it should disappear by 20 weeks. Its persistence after 20 weeks is considered abnormal. In a blind child, however, it may persist beyond 20 weeks normally and is called apparent hand regard.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2SD. This is most likely due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chronic malnutrition
Low height for the age (height for age < -2SD) in children indicates chronic malnutrition and stunting.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3 year old child to display?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Spoon handling
The ability to handle a spoon well and feed self is usually developed by 24 months (2 years) and would be expected in a 3 year old child.

questions.text: A previously healthy term infant suddenly develops respiratory distress on day 3 of life. An echocardiogram reveals coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for immediate stabilization of this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prostaglandin therapy
This infant’s symptoms started when his ductus arteriosus began to close. A continuous intravenous infusion of prostaglandin will keep the ductus open and allow blood flow to reach past the area of coarctation and perfuse the lower portion of the body. Surgery provides definitive repair.

questions.text: Following a delivery complicated by shoulder dystocia, the baby is noted to have a deformity in the right upper limb. On inspection, the orthopedics JR notes an adducted, internally rotated arm and a pronated forearm. Which nerve roots are affected here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

C5 and C6 
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of Erb-Duchenne paralysis. The injury is limited to the 5th and 6th cervical nerve roots. The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation of the forearm. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with edema, oliguria, and frothy urine. He has no history of similar complaints. His urine was positive for 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs/WBCs, and no casts. His serum albumin was 2.4 gm/dL and serum creatinine was 0.5 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Minimal change disease
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of minimal change disease. It most frequently manifests between the ages of 2 and 6 years. Edema is typically seen in children and is first noticed in the lower extremities and around the eyes. The absence of hypertension and extensive hematuria are key indicators of minimal change disease.

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Female pseudohermaphroditism
CAH most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism because the most common enzyme deficiency is a 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Female pseudohermaphrodite, a virilized female, is a genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia looks like that of a male. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Any of the above
A tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn can be a presentation of occult spinal dysraphism. It is the defective fusion of the midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures. In this, most of the patients will have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, including a small dimple, a tuft of hair, and subcutaneous lipoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Color blindness

Color blindness is an X-linked disorder.

choices.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.
Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.
Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
The given clinical scenario of a child with cold feet with diminished lower limb pulses and radio femoral delay is suggestive of coarctation of the aorta. It is caused by coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

questions.text: A 3-hour-old neonate with apnea has been on bag and mask ventilation for the last 30 seconds. She has now started taking spontaneous breaths. The heart rate is still between 100 and 110/min. What is your next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


As per the NRP algorithm, at any time during resuscitation, if the HR > 100 and spontaneous breathing resumes then discontinue ventilation.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI). Diarrhea is defined as a change in consistency and frequency of stools that occurs more than 3 times a day. Diarrhea, if associated with blood in stools, is called dysentery. If the episodes subside within 7 days, it is called acute diarrhea. If it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is called persistent diarrhea.

questions.text: The most common pituitary adenoma diagnosed in childhood is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The most commonly diagnosed adenomas during childhood are prolactinoma > corticotropinoma > somatotropinoma.

questions.text: The most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis among the pediatric age group is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis among the given options.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. Three days after starting the medication, he developed torticollis and orofacio-lingual movements. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute muscular dystonia

The patient has developed acute muscular dystonia (spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, and back) which is an extrapyramidal side effect of haloperidol. This occurs within 1-5 days of drug intake.

questions.text: An employee in a company is friends with everyone in his office. He goes to different parties every weekend and says he loves talking to new people. This trait is described under which dimension of personality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Extraversion

The traits of being talkative, sociable, and outgoing are described under extraversion. It is one of the five personality traits of the big five personality theory. It indicates how outgoing and social a person is.

choices.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


According to the WHO, stress can be defined as any type of change that causes physical, emotional, or psychological strain. Stress is your body's response to anything that requires attention or action. Everyone experiences stress to some degree.

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent suffers from bulimia nervosa and is very depressed. She is also suffering from insomnia and apathy. Which of the following medications should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bupropion


Seizure disorders and eating disorders are contraindications for bupropion because of its possible lowering of the seizure threshold and its anorectic effects.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has been taking medication (the name of which she does not remember) for her psychiatric condition. She complains of excessive thirst and urinating “all the time.” Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bipolar disorder 

This patient has symptoms of diabetes insipidus, a side effect of lithium used in the treatment of bipolar disease.
